creator: mhilpert@gmx.de
text:
I try to read the build number from the properties file build.number via the 
<property> task:

---
<buildnumber file="${java}${file.separator}build.number"/>
<property resource="${java}${file.separator}build.number"/>
<echo message="Build number= ${build.number}" />
---

but the task does not find the file even though it is there (triple checked 
file name and directory path name):

---
increase build.number:
    [property] Unable to find resource D:\data\prjs\amc\prg\java\build.number
        [echo] Build number= ${build.number}
---

creator: bodewig@apache.org
text:
Don't use resource when you are looking for a file, there is a difference between
those attributes (resources searches in your CLASSPATH).  Please see the manual
of the property task for more details.

BTW, there is no reason to use ${file.separator}, Ant will get it right
automatically, no matter whether you use / or \.

but the documentation of (ant 1.5.3) <loadproperties> (that works) says:

"This is equivalent to <property file="..."/> except that it supports nested 
<filterchain> elements and it cannot be specified outside a target."

so, <loadproperties srcFile="bla.properties"> should be the exact same es 
<property file="bla.properties"> ... shouldn't it?
creator: mhilpert@gmx.de
bodewig@apache.org
text:
You are absolutely right, <loadproperties srcFile="bla.properties"> should
not only be equivalent to <property file="bla.properties">, it actually is.

Look into your example in this report, you don't use the file attribute of
property, but its resource attribute.
